result.text:
看了宝玉老师的文章，很多都和我的体验相吻合。干脆借这个机会，点个炮点评一下最近中文区刷屏的一些所谓的 Skill：

如果你的 Skill 中只有一个 https://t.co/3xhJhqVILk，那这玩意和写个 Promt/Command  有啥区别？不用 Reference 是“渐进式披露”这五个字看不懂吗？不用 Scripts 是觉得每次都让 AI 临时代码稳定性更强吗？

之前我已经反复强调过很多次了，Skill 的确是一个把个体经验转化为 AI 技能的低门槛方案。但是，低门槛不代表没有门槛啊！就算是可以用官方的 skill-creator skill 套娃式让 AI 写 skill，但写完了总得自己 Review 一下看看是不是靠谱吧。

更何况，从我自己的实践来看，官方的 skill-creator skill 也不是那么靠谱，光 https://t.co/3xhJhqVILk 不要超过 500 行，以及不要在里面塞示例和代码这些基本规范，它就经常遵循的不太好。

所以，我的解决方案是自己在官方的基础上，构建了一个增强版的 agent-skill-helper skill，从命名到架构，从SOP到代码，都有对应的 SOP 通过提示词和脚本调用来负责。

而对于最终生成的 Skill，我也是一定会进行人工审核和反复测试的，甚至这个测试的过程比写代码还要频繁和严谨。

至于持续进化，那更是 Skill 使用中的日常，这里还有一个小技巧：多在 Reference 中放点示例，并在 https://t.co/3xhJhqVILk 中要求多加参考，最终出来的结果稳定性会好很多很多。

最后，说个不怕得罪人的话：万变不离其宗，重要的是认知能力，如果你写不好 workflow，大概率你也写不好 skill。

It was on January 10, 2018, when Valaree Schwab left school to have lunch. While she was out, the 16-year-old was attacked by a group of "school bullies" who beat and kicked her to the ground and stole her keys. 

When she followed them to another fast food place to retrieve her belongings, Z'inah Brown, Carl Booker, and Dominique Slack stabbed Valaree in the chest, puncturing her heart and lungs. 

Valaree spent her last conscious moments "gasping for air, clutching the hand of a young cashier."

Carl Booker and Dominique Slack were both sentenced to "shock probation." This involved six months of incarceration in Westchester County Jail followed by five years of probation. 
So those 2 are out and ready to kill again.

Zina Brown received 17 years in prison. She's eligible for release after the 17 years minus any good time credits.

result.text:
《宝玉误给scammer带货：扒皮所谓的AI研究员的诈骗手段》
在 @dotey  这篇翻译自 @elenakvcs 的原文高达 159万阅读的文章里，评论里出现一个很有道理的质疑声：这个叫elena的研究员每天读论文，测模型，写报告，却从来没写过代码？能研究出来啥？
看到这里，AI圈的同学们可能还没反应过来，币圈的同学-们倒是会心一笑了：这不就币圈那群独立研究员常见的人设么？按币圈的节奏，是不是真有这个人都不一定。
而我简单的扒了一下皮，发现结果比想象的更恶劣：这个研究员根本就是个典型的币圈scammer号伪装的AI研究员。
---
首先让我们缕一下时间线：
2025年10月该账号注册。
12月31号左右，粉丝数已经达到6万+，但此时一个帖子都没有。更需要注意的是这个账号在去年11月底粉丝数更多，达到了近8万粉丝。
2026年1月1号左右连续转帖 @ManusAI 的帖子。
1月4号发出现存第一帖。
1月5号开始fo @ManusAI 。
1月6号发出该159万阅读的文章。
1月11号（今天）为止，该账户一共只有15个帖子。

而该账户的蓝V的follow数，也不到30个（统计到1月11号为止），明显少于正常6w follower的数量，且有多个英文圈著名宣传meme币的诈骗犯。
---
所以很明显，从这个粉丝数偏好，以及多次改名来看，这个账号非常符合 币圈meme币项目/Scammer的小号 的特征。现在因为币圈流动性太差，于是这个小号秽土转生成一个了所谓“AI研究员”。
自然，它的文章里也就充满了不必要的夸张和标榜。
当然，只是翻译了一篇文章自然没什么害处，但我为什么在标题上警告说 @dotey 误给scammer带货呢？
那是因为这个文章和这个账号的本意是给一个叫做 vibecodingmXXXXrs （为防止误加已经打码部分字符）的tg频道引流。
虽然现在这个频道还没分享什么内容，但很明显，之后它要么是给虚拟meme币带货，更恶劣的可能是给大家分享带毒的Skills来入侵你的电脑（可以参照 @evilcos 的 https://t.co/L23qGBvFBp)。

为防止更多的人上当受骗，求转发求扩散。

@rickawsb @dongxi_nlp @DFarm_club @gasikaramada @colinwu @penny777 @nake13 @chaowxyz @colinwu @DemonTime @brucexu_eth @CryptoPainter @starzq @wey_gu @timtimtim_eth @supermao @strrlthedev

result.text:
The UK is regulating itself into irrelevance.

The plan was to build 531 km of high-speed rail.

Before laying track, contractors had to:

- Complete a 350-page “social value” assessment
- Guarantee 30% female representation
- Guarantee 20% ethnic-minority representation

The outcome was predictable.

- Original timeline: 2010-2026
- After years of delays and overruns, ~50% of the project was cancelled
- Remaining construction now stretches beyond 2033
- Cost: ~£70B for just 40% of the route (~£311M per km)

Meanwhile, China:

- Built ~50,000 km of high-speed rail in 17 years
- Averaging ~3,000 km per year
- At a cost of ~£14M per km

China builds high-speed rail ~200x faster and ~22x cheaper.

Now apply the same regulatory mindset to the energy transition....
and the scale of waste becomes obvious.

result.text:
I’ve spent a long time thinking about accountability, and I don’t think it’s the missing ingredient most people think it is.

I think what’s missing is a sense of internal safety while being accountable. Without that, accountability doesn’t produce action. It produces avoidance.

- We all know what a dysfunctional environment looks like.
- A workplace where mistakes are punished, not learned from.
- A team where people cover their backs instead of taking initiative.
- A friendship group or online space where everything turns into judgment, hierarchy, or quiet competition.

Nothing meaningful happens there.
People stall. They hide. They do the minimum.
Not because they’re lazy—but because the system is hostile.

Now here’s the uncomfortable part.

Most people are running that exact system inside themselves.

- They fail.
- They miss an opportunity.
- They don’t get what they wanted.

And the response isn’t curiosity or course-correction.
It’s internal punishment.

- Harsh self-talk.
- Withdrawal.
- Bad moods used like a whip.
- A subtle sense of “this proves something about me.”

That isn’t accountability.
That’s a hostile work environment—internalised.

And we already know what hostile environments do to performance.

There’s good evidence for this.
High self-criticism is associated with more procrastination, more anxiety, lower persistence, and poorer learning after failure.
When mistakes threaten identity or worth, the nervous system shifts into protection mode. People avoid exposure. They disengage. They choose short-term relief over long-term progress.

That’s not a mindset issue.
That’s basic conditioning.

What’s strange is how normalised this inner violence is.
We talk endlessly about culture, leadership, and psychological safety at work—then go home and treat ourselves in ways no functional team would tolerate.

Here’s a simple thought experiment.

Imagine someone you care about tried something important and failed. BUT imagine responding the way most people respond internally.

- Cold.
- Disappointed.
- Sarcastic.
- Withholding warmth until results improve.

Most people recoil when they picture doing that to someone else. Yet they do it to themselves every day and call it “standards.”

Jordan Peterson once remarked that a large number of people he spoke to didn’t need radical transformation—they needed a little encouragement in their lives. 
What struck me wasn’t just that many don’t receive it from others.
It’s that MANY are incapable of giving it to themselves.

That’s staggering when you really sit with it.

We walk around whipping ourselves with moods, pressure, and self-contempt because we think that’s how progress works.
As if growth requires hostility.
As if effort must hurt to count.

What if that assumption is simply wrong?

What if the reason “doing the thing” feels so hard isn’t because you lack discipline—but because every attempt comes with an internal cost your system is no longer willing to pay?

So here’s a radical experiment.
Not motivational. Not philosophical. Practical.

For 30 days, try this:

Every time you do the thing—especially when it goes badly—respond with encouragement instead of punishment.
Not fake positivity. Not denial. Just acknowledgment:

“You showed up.”
“You tried.”
“That mattered.”

Even when the outcome is poor.
Especially then.

This isn’t about lowering standards.
It’s about changing the environment in which standards operate.

Because no system—human or mechanical—learns well under constant threat.

If you’re running a hostile inner workplace, nothing gets built.

And if you keep calling that accountability, you’ll keep wondering why you know exactly what to do—and still don’t do it.

I’m not interested in more pressure.
I’m interested in what actually works.

Try the experiment.
Then look honestly at the results.

You may find that the thing that finally moves the needle for you isn’t as many claim on the internet and in most self help books as wanting it more— but instead no longer needing to protect yourself from yourself.

legacy.full_text:
I’ve spent a long time thinking about accountability, and I don’t think it’s the missing ingredient most people think it is.

I think what’s missing is a sense of internal safety while being accountable. Without that, accountability doesn’t produce action. It produces avoidance.
